sen.j: 連歌（れんが）は日本の伝統的詩形のひとつで、複数の人間で和歌の上句と下句を繋げていくものである。
sen.e: Renga is a traditional form of poetry, and Kaminoku (the first part of a poem) and Shimonoku (the latter part of a poem) are linked together by several people.
Renga is a traditional form of poetry, and the kaminoku (the first part of a poem) and shimonoku (the latter part of a poem) are linked together by several people.
Renga is a traditional form of poetry, and the kaminoku (the first part of a poem) and shimonoku (the latter part of a poem) are linked together by several people.

sen.j: 句の繋げ方には規則があり、また句数によって歌仙、百吟などいくつもの形式がある。
sen.e: There are rules of linking poems and many forms like Kasen (superior poets) and Hyakugin (a type of Renga), according to the number of phrases.
There are rules for linking poems, and many forms, such as the kasen (superior poetry) and hyakugin (a type of renga), are structured according to the number of phrases.
There are rules for linking poems, and many forms, such as the kasen (superior poetry) and hyakugin (a type of renga), are structured according to the number of phrases.

sen.j: 連歌は「筑波（つくば）の道」とも称されるが、これは連歌の起源を『古事記』にある、筑波山を詠みこんだ、ヤマトタケル（やまとたけるのみこと）と御火焼翁（みひたきのおきな）との唱和問答歌とすることによる。
sen.e: Renga is also called 'Tsukuba no Michi (street of Tsukuba)' because the origin of Renga goes back to the Showa-Mondoka (chorus poetries in the form of question and answer) between Yamatotakeru no Mikoto and Mihitaki no Okina, which depicted Mt. Tsukuba and was collected in "Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters)"
sen.cmt: http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=つくば&dtype=0&stype=0&dname=0ss&pagenum=11&index=113072700000http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=筑波山&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=14288012365300http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=ヤマトタケル&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=21665118584100
sen.e: Renga is also called 'Tsukuba no Michi (street of Tsukuba)' because the origin of renga goes back to the Showa-Mondoka (chorus poetry in the form of question and answer) between Yamatotakeru no Mikoto and Mihitaki no Okina, which depicted Mt. Tsukuba and was collected in "Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters)."

Renga is also called 'Tsukuba no Michi (street of Tsukuba)' because the origin of renga goes back to the Showa-Mondoka (chorus poetry in the form of question and answer) between Yamatotakeru no Mikoto and Mihitaki no Okina, which depicted Mt. Tsukuba and was collected in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters).
sen.cmt: "Kojiki (Records of Ancient Matters)."→"Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters).に変更しました。

sen.j: そのもっとも早い形は八代集にみられる短連歌（三十一文字の上の句と下の句を別々の作者が詠む）である。
sen.e: The earliest form of Renga can be seen in Hachidaishu (the first eight collections of waka compiled by imperial command) as a form of Tanrenga (thirty-one-syllable poem the first and the latter part of which are made by different composer).
sen.cmt: 「八代集」の訳語は「新和英大辞典（研究社）」より（以下、「和大」と表記）http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=短連歌&dtype=0&dname=0na&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=13669011809000
sen.e: The earliest form of renga can be seen in the Hachidaishu (the first eight collections of waka compiled by imperial command) as a form of tanrenga (a 31-syllable poem in which the first and latter parts are made by different composers).

The earliest form of renga can be seen in the Hachidaishu (the first eight collections of waka compiled by imperial command) as a form of tanrenga (a 31-syllable poem in which the first and latter parts are made by different composers).

sen.j: 中世の鎌倉時代から100句を基準とする長連歌の形式が整えられ、南北朝時代 (日本)を経て室町時代が最盛期とされる。
sen.e: Since medieval Kamakura era, the Chorenga had been formed into a hundred-stanza sequence, and after the Nanbokucho era, it reached the golden age in the Muromachi era.
Since the medieval Kamakura period, the Chorenga had evolved into a hundred-stanza sequence, and after the Nanbokucho period it reached its golden age in the Muromachi period.

Since the medieval Kamakura period, the Chorenga had evolved into a hundred-stanza sequence, and after the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) it reached its golden age in the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: 南北朝時代を the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) としました。

sen.j: 連歌は能楽と並び室町文化を代表する遊戯の1つとされる。
sen.e: Renga is considered one of the games which represent Muromachi Culture along with Nogaku.
Renga is considered one of the games that represent the Muromachi culture, along with Nogaku.
Renga is considered one of the games that represent the Muromachi culture, along with Nogaku.

sen.j: 室町時代には二条良基、宗祇、心敬などの連歌師が出現し、貴族の邸宅や有力寺社などで連歌会が催された。
sen.e: In the Muromachi era, Rengashi (poet who only writes Renga) appeared like Yoshimoto NIJO, Sogi, Shinkei, etc., and Rengakai was held at the residences of court nobles and leading temples.
During the Muromachi period, Rengashi (poets who only write renga) appeared. Such as Yoshimoto NIJO, Sogi, Shinkei, etc., and rengakai were held at the residences of court nobles and leading temples.

During the Muromachi period, Rengashi (poets who wrote only renga) such as Yoshimoto NIJO, Sogi, Shinkei and others appeared, and rengakai were held at the residences of court nobles and leading temples.

sen.j: 応仁の乱で京都の文化が地方伝播すると、連歌も畿内だけでなく、日本各地で行われるようになる。
sen.e: Once the culture of Kyoto spread to the countryside, Renga came to be composed not only in Kinai District but also all over Japan.
Once the culture of Kyoto spread to the countryside, renga came to be composed not only in Kinai District but also all over Japan.
Once the culture of Kyoto spread to the countryside amid the turmoil of the Onin War, renga came to be composed not only in the Kinai District but throughout Japan as well.
sen.cmt: by the turmoil of the Onin war補足

sen.j: 集団制作による詩形である連歌は講と結びついて発展した。
sen.e: Renga, a poem composed by a group, developed being related with Ko (meeting to lecture Buddhist scriptures).
Renga, a poem composed by a group, developed in relation to the ko (meeting for a lecture on Buddhist scriptures).
Renga, a poem composed by a group, developed in relation to the ko (meeting for a lecture on Buddhist scriptures).

sen.j: とくに鎌倉時代後期から菅原道真信仰と結びついた。
sen.e: It had been linked with especially SUGAWARA no Michizane Shinko (To have faith in SUGAWARA no Michizane as a god) since the late Kamakura era.
It had been particularly linked with SUGAWARA no Michizane Shinko (to have faith in SUGAWARA no Michizane as a god) since the late Kamakura period.
It had been particularly linked with SUGAWARA no Michizane Shinko (to have faith in SUGAWARA no Michizane as a god) since the late Kamakura period.

sen.j: 連歌を目的とする天神講を特に天神講連歌会と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Tenjinko Festival for making Renga was especially called Tenjinko Festival Rengakai.
The Tenjinko Festival for making renga was especially called "Tenjinko Festival Rengakai."
The Tenjinko Festival for making renga was especially called "Tenjinko Festival Rengakai."

sen.j: 講を結び、図像をかかげて天神供養を行い、もって連歌を手向けとするものである。
sen.e: It is a festival in which the lecture is given, a memorial service for the deified spirit of Sugawara no Michizane with an icon is held, and Renga is offered.
sen.cmt: 天神の訳語は「和大」より
sen.e: It was a festival in which the lecture was given, a memorial service for the deified spirit of Sugawara no Michizane with an icon was held, and renga were offered.
It was a festival in which the lecture was given, a memorial service for the deified spirit of Sugawara no Michizane with an icon was held, and renga were offered.

sen.j: こうした連歌会は大和国を中心に発達し、室町時代を通じて畿内から各地へ伝播していった。
sen.e: Such Rengakai developed mainly in Yamato Province, and through the Muromachi era it spread from Kinai District to the various areas.
sen.cmt: http://kotobank.jp/word/大和国「～国」は、「～ Province」で統一しました。
sen.e: Such rengakai developed mainly in Yamato Province, and through the Muromachi period it spread from the Kinai district to various other areas.
Such rengakai developed mainly in Yamato Province, and through the Muromachi period it spread from the Kinai district to various other areas.

sen.j: 天神講連歌会記録としては大和国の室生村の染田天神連歌文書などが伝来する。
sen.e: A record of the Tenjinko Festival Rengakai has been transmitted such as Someda Tenjin Rengakai held in Muromura, Yamato Province.
A record of the Tenjinko Festival Rengakai has been transmitted, such as Someda Tenjin Rengakai held in Muromura, Yamato Province.
A record of the Tenjinko Festival Rengakai has been transmitted, such as Someda Tenjin Rengakai held in Muromura, Yamato Province.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)から近世にかけても連歌は必須の教養とされた。
sen.e: From the Sengoku period to the early modern times, Renga was considered an essential education.
From the Sengoku period to the early modern times, renga was considered an essential part of education.
From the Sengoku period to the early modern times, renga was considered an essential part of education.

sen.j: 戦国時代には里村紹巴が出て、連歌書を多く著すとともに、諸大名と交際し、教養としての連歌の地位を新興の大名のうちにも確立させた。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period, Joha SATOMURA appeared and wrote many books on Renga, having social relations with some Daimyo (feudal lord), and established an educational position of Renga among the newly appearing Daimyo.

During the Sengoku period, Joha SATOMURA appeared and wrote many books on renga, having social relations with some daimyo (feudal lords), and established an educational position of renga among the newly appearing daimyo.

During the Sengoku period, Joha SATOMURA appeared and wrote many books on renga, having social relations with some daimyo (feudal lords), and established an educational position of renga among the newly appearing daimyo.

sen.j: 里村家は後に徳川家に仕え、征夷大将軍の指南役として連歌界を指導した。
sen.e: The SATOMURA family later served the TOKUGAWA family, and led the Renga society as an instructor of Seiitaishogun (commander in chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader).

The SATOMURA family later served the TOKUGAWA family, and led the renga society as an instructor of seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians; great, unifying leader).
The Satomura family later served the Tokugawa family, and led the renga society as an instructor of seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").
sen.cmt: SATOMURA→SatomuraTOKUGAWA→Tokugawaseiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians; great, unifying leader)→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")に変更しました。

sen.j: 一方戦国末期には、荒木田守武、山崎宗鑑などにより俳諧連歌がはじまる。
sen.e: While at the end of the Sengoku period, Moritake ARAKIDA and Sokan YAMAZAKI started Haikairenga (a type of Renga).
At the end of the Sengoku period, Moritake ARAKIDA and Sokan YAMAZAKI started Haikairenga (a type of renga).
At the end of the Sengoku period, Moritake ARAKIDA and Sokan YAMAZAKI started Haikairenga (a type of renga).

sen.j: これは伝統的な宮廷文化の枠組みの中にあった連歌の題材を、広く世相に求め、伝統的な詩形や題材と卑近なものの組みあわせのうちにおかしみを見出そうとする試みである。
sen.e: This is an attempt to pursue the subject matter of Renga in the social conditions, and try to find out humor in the combination of traditional poetic form and something familiar.
This was an attempt to pursue the subject matter of renga in the social conditions, and to try to find humor in the combination of a traditional poetic form and something familiar.
This was an attempt to pursue the subject matter of renga in the social conditions, and to try to find humor in the combination of a traditional poetic form and something familiar.

sen.j: 『犬筑波集』などがある。
sen.e: There is a book like "Inu Tsukubashu."
There are books such as "Inu Tsukubashu."
There are books such as "Inu Tsukubashu."

sen.j: 江戸時代には俳諧連歌が隆盛となり、上方から井原西鶴、松尾芭蕉らを輩出したが、連歌自体は廃れた。
sen.e: In the Edo era, Haikairenga reached its height, and Saikaku IHARA and Basho MATSUO appeared from the Kyoto-Osaka area, but Renga itself became obsolete.
During the Edo period Haikairenga reached its zenith, and Saikaku IHARA and Basho MATSUO appeared from the Kyoto-Osaka area; however, renga had become obsolete.
During the Edo period Haikairenga reached its zenith, and Saikaku IHARA and Basho MATSUO appeared from the Kyoto-Osaka area; however, renga had become obsolete.

sen.j: 俳諧連歌もまた江戸後期に至り月並流といわれる形式を重視したものに変化し、明治になり正岡子規の俳諧から俳句への革新によっていったんは廃れた。
sen.e: Haikairenga was also changed into the Tsukinami School which took a form seriously, and it came to be outdated once in the reform of poem from Haikai to Haiku in the Meiji era.
Haikairenga was also changed into the Tsukinami School, which took the form seriously, and it came to be outdated once in the reform of poetry from haikai to haiku during the Meiji period.
Haikairenga was also changed into the Tsukinami School, which took the form seriously, but during the Meiji period it became outdated in the reform of poetry by Shiki MASAOKA from haikai to haiku.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦ののちは、大岡信など現代詩詩人のなかから連歌の集団制作性に注目し、伝統的な枠にあまり囚われない集団詩としての連歌を実践する試みがある一方、伝統詩形としての連歌に再び回帰する動きもある。
sen.e: After WWII, modern poets like Makoto OOKA paid attentions to the nature of group creation of Renga, and tried to compose Renga as a group poem being free from tradition, while some people returned to the Renga as a traditional poetic form.

After WWII, modern poets like Makoto OOKA paid attention to the nature of group creation of Renga, and tried to compose renga as group poems being free from tradition, while some people returned to the renga as a traditional poetic form.

After World War II, modern poets like Makoto OOKA paid attention to the nature of group creation of Renga, and tried to compose renga as group poems in a manner free from tradition, while some people returned to the renga as a traditional poetic form.
sen.cmt: WWII→World War II 他の記事と合わせる

sen.j: 前者は Renga として日本語以外の言語でも実践を行っている。
sen.e: The former is practiced as Renga in languages other than Japanese.
The former is practiced as renga in languages other than Japanese.
The former is practiced as renga in languages other than Japanese.

sen.j: 後者は深川芭蕉庵の連歌会などを催し、伝統的な宗匠 と連衆による連歌句作を行っている。
sen.e: The latter holds Rengakai such as Fukagawa Bashoan (the hut, which Basho lived, in Fukagawa), and composes Renga by traditional master and Renju (people who attends the party to compose poetries).
The latter holds rengakai such as Fukagawa Bashoan (the hut in Fukagawa in which Basho lived), and composes renga by traditional master and renju (people who attend the party to compose poetry).
The latter holds rengakai such as Fukagawa Bashoan (the hut in Fukagawa in which Basho lived), and composes renga by traditional master and renju (people who attend the party to compose poetry).

sen.j: また両者の傾向とも、インターネットによる実践を行う試みが各所で行われている。
sen.e: And both groups are trying to practice on the Internet at all areas.
Both groups are endeavoring to continue their practice through various channels of the Internet.
Both groups are endeavoring to continue their practice through various channels of the Internet.

sen.j: ただし、このような復興の動きがある反面、連歌を行う人口や結社の数は、俳句に比べれば僅少といえる状態にとどまっている。
sen.e: Though there is a movement of revival, the number of association and people who make Renga is still small compared with that of Haiku.
Though there is a revival movement, the number of associations and people who make renga is still small by comparison to that of haiku.
Although there is a revival movement, the number of associations and people who make renga is still small by comparison to that of haiku.
